contentSection.headline: Master Labor Relations Strategies That Protect Your Organization
contentSection.description: Comprehensive Labor Relations is 2 intensive days where you'll master the NLRB landscape, union avoidance strategies, election readiness, and collective bargaining techniques—working through realistic scenarios with experienced labor attorneys, not checklists and theory.
benefits: Complete labor relations framework – NLRB compliance, handbook policies after Stericycle, joint-employer rules, and organizing risk assessment
Union avoidance strategies – Lawful hiring practices, supervisor training for §7 compliance, and proactive employee relations
Election and bargaining expertise – Campaign playbooks, good-faith bargaining, and CBA administration
Professional certification – Earn your certificate plus 13 SHRM/HRCI/CLE continuing education credits

header.title: What You'll Master in 2 Days
header.description: A comprehensive labor relations framework covering NLRB compliance, union avoidance, election readiness, collective bargaining, and advanced topics that protect your organization.

blocks.label: Full Program
blocks.title: Comprehensive Labor Relations
blocks.description: Navigate the complex terrain of organizing risk, employee handbooks, union elections, and collective bargaining with proven strategies.

competencyGroups.title: The Current NLRB & Organizing Landscape
competencyGroups.description: Key shifts in elections, handbooks, and joint-employer liability.

skills.title: Elections & recognition after NLRB Cemex decision
skills.description: Faster elections; higher risk of bargaining orders for ULPs; what "card-check-adjacent" and new GC guidance mean in practice.

skills.title: Handbooks after NLRB Stericycle decision
skills.description: Why neutral rules (civility, confidentiality, social media, devices) can still violate §7; how to rewrite with context-specific justifications.

skills.title: Joint-employer status (where it stands now)
skills.description: 2023 rule invalidated; prior standard effectively back—implications for franchise/contracting models and vendor oversight.

competencyGroups.title: Practical Guidance for Non-Union Workplaces
competencyGroups.description: Reduce organizing heat with lawful hiring, onboarding, and training.

skills.title: Hiring & onboarding practices
skills.description: Lower ULP risk; orientation scripts that avoid "captive audience" pitfalls.

skills.title: The three big sparks for organizing
skills.description: Scheduling/fairness, safety (including psychological safety), and transparency (wages/career paths)—how HR cools them with credible channels and swift fixes.

skills.title: Manager training for §7 in non-union settings
skills.description: Protected concerted activity on Slack/Teams and group chats; where discipline goes wrong under Stericycle.

competencyGroups.title: Election Readiness & Campaign Law
competencyGroups.description: Operate within accelerated timelines while preserving laboratory conditions.

skills.title: Campaign playbook: Do / Don't
skills.description: Practical rules for message discipline under accelerated timelines; maintaining true laboratory conditions.

skills.title: Access, equal time, and solicitation rules
skills.description: Apply solicitation/distribution and email/Teams policies—updated for hybrid work.

skills.title: Post-election objections and reruns
skills.description: Prevent and defend against objections to avoid costly reruns.

competencyGroups.title: Collective Bargaining
competencyGroups.description: Proposals that matter, documentation, and aligning handbooks with CBAs.

skills.title: Setting the table
skills.description: Management rights, grievance/arbitration, zipper, information requests, technology/data clauses, and safety.

skills.title: Good-faith bargaining
skills.description: Information requests, surface bargaining risks, and documenting proposals/counterproposals.

skills.title: Handbook ↔ CBA alignment
skills.description: Avoid conflicts and unintended past-practice creation.

competencyGroups.title: Strikes, Pickets, and Employer Response
competencyGroups.description: Protected vs unprotected actions, lawful responses, and contingency planning.

skills.title: Types of strikes and lockouts
skills.description: Intermittent/partial strike pitfalls; replacements and lawful lockout strategy.

skills.title: Picketing & social media amplification
skills.description: What changes in a viral era and how to respond lawfully.

skills.title: Contingency planning
skills.description: Checklists and communication protocols that minimize disruption.

competencyGroups.title: Operating Under a CBA
competencyGroups.description: Grievance handling, settlements, records, and change management.

skills.title: Grievances to arbitration
skills.description: Intake triage, settlement tools, record-building, arbitrator selection, and "just cause" proofs.

skills.title: Past practice, side letters, zipper clauses
skills.description: How to manage change mid-term without creating legal traps.

competencyGroups.title: Successorship, Acquisitions & Restructuring
competencyGroups.description: When buyers must recognize a union and how to diligence LR risks.

skills.title: Successor obligations
skills.description: When a buyer must recognize a union; hiring decisions that trigger duty to bargain.

skills.title: Alter-ego/single-employer risks
skills.description: ER/LR due diligence checklists including wage/hour and privacy/data issues.

competencyGroups.title: Special Watch-Items for LR Professionals
competencyGroups.description: Transparency, privacy/monitoring, and cross-law impacts to watch.

skills.title: Pay transparency (multi-state)
skills.description: Job-post salary ranges, internal equity communications, and how transparency interacts with CBA wage grids.

skills.title: State privacy & monitoring
skills.description: CPRA employee data and beyond—impacts on investigations, monitoring, and CBA data requests.

faculty.name: Ray Deeny, Esq.
faculty.title: Partner at Taft Stettinius & Hollister LLP
faculty.bio: Ray is widely regarded as a dean of labor and employment law, known for his encyclopedic knowledge and unmatched command of workplace regulations. For over 40 years, he has represented management nationwide, blending a powerhouse advisory practice with a formidable litigation record.

faculty.name: John F. Wymer, III, Esq.
faculty.title: Partner, Labor & Employment at Thompson Hine LLP
faculty.bio: John F. Wymer is a nationally recognized labor and employment attorney and partner in Thompson Hine LLP's Labor & Employment group. With decades of experience, he represents public and private sector employers nationwide in employment discrimination, wage-and-hour, labor negotiations, union matters, ERISA claims, and more.

faculty.name: Wayne W. Williams, Esq.
faculty.title: Founder, Law Offices of Wayne W. Williams
faculty.bio: Wayne Williams is a distinguished employment and labor law attorney based in Colorado Springs. As the founder of his own firm, he advises and represents employers on a wide range of issues including employment discrimination, harassment, wrongful discharge, wage and hour compliance, and traditional labor law.

faculty.name: Patrick Scully, Esq.
faculty.title: Partner at Foley Hoag
faculty.bio: Patrick Scully primarily focuses on labor law issues and helps clients successfully navigate complex and persistent claims from international and local labor unions. Patrick's work includes unfair labor practice charges and representation cases as well as federal and state court litigation.

faculty.name: Amy J. Zdravecky, Esq.
faculty.title: Partner at Barnes & Thornburg LLP
faculty.bio: Amy represents employers across industries including retail, hospitality, manufacturing, transportation, and healthcare. She advises on employee relations, union avoidance, collective bargaining, harassment prevention, and compliance with key employment laws like Title VII, ADA, ADEA, FMLA, and FCRA.

faq.question: What happens after I register?
faq.answer: Within minutes, you'll receive an invoice email. Once payment is processed, you can schedule your complimentary pre-program consultation (10-15 minutes) to discuss labor relations challenges you're currently facing and identify which scenarios will have the biggest impact for you. Pre-program materials arrive one week before your session starts.

faq.question: What's the difference between in-person and virtual formats?
faq.answer: Both formats feature the same practicing attorney instructors, current labor relations methodologies, and professional credits. In-person provides face-to-face networking with other HR and LR professionals. Virtual delivers the same live instruction via Zoom with full Q&A capability. Choose the format that fits your schedule—the quality and content remain identical.

faq.question: What continuing education credits will I earn?
faq.answer: The 2-day program provides 13 SHRM/HRCI/CLE credits. Plus, your enrollment includes 12 months of quarterly employment law updates (4 sessions × 1.5 credits each = 6 additional credits), bringing your total to 19 credits.

faq.question: Is this the same as Block I of the Certificate in Employee Relations Law?
faq.answer: Yes. Comprehensive Labor Relations is Block I of the full Certificate in Employee Relations Law program. You can take it as a standalone 2-day program, or combine it with Discrimination Prevention & Defense (Block II) and Special Issues in Employment Law (Block III) to earn the full certificate.

faq.question: I work in a non-union environment. Is this program relevant for me?
faq.answer: Absolutely. A significant portion of the program covers union avoidance strategies, recognizing organizing risks, and maintaining compliance in non-union settings. You'll learn how to reduce organizing heat through lawful hiring, onboarding, and supervisor training—critical knowledge even if you've never faced a union campaign.

faq.question: How current is the labor relations content?
faq.answer: Very. The curriculum addresses the latest NLRB developments including the Cemex decision's impact on elections, Stericycle's effect on handbook policies, and the current joint-employer standard. Our instructors update content based on cases they're currently handling.

faq.question: Does the $1,375 program fee include everything?
faq.answer: Yes. Your enrollment includes all live instruction from practicing labor attorneys, complete program materials, 13 continuing education credits, pre-program consultation, 12 months of quarterly employment law updates (4 sessions, $1,588 value), permanent access to updated resources, and alumni benefits for all future programs. The only additional cost would be travel and lodging if you choose in-person format.

faq.question: Can I apply this toward the full Certificate in Employee Relations Law?
faq.answer: Yes. Comprehensive Labor Relations (Block I) counts toward the full certificate. You can complete the remaining blocks—Discrimination Prevention & Defense (Block II) and Special Issues in Employment Law (Block III)—at any future session to earn the complete Certificate in Employee Relations Law.
